text:
ELISE JONES: Good
afternoon, everyone.

I'm Elise Jones,
from Boston College.

It can take courage
to be your real self

in the face of
messages from people,

including you, that say
you should be someone else.

Maybe everyone in
your high school

is going to be a
doctor or a lawyer,

and you want to work
with your hands.

Maybe you want to fit in
after moving to a new country,

but are afraid of
alienating your family.

Maybe you wanted to shake
things up in a workplace

where everyone is
expected to tow the line.

Pushing back against things
that don't feel right for you

can be especially
hard when it involves

going against norms that are
part of your own community.

For my dissertation,
I'm studying

heterosexual married
couples who were raised

in a family-focused
faith community, where,

from their youth,
women were socialized

to be full-time caregivers, and
men to provide for the family.

Messages that were amplified
to white upper middle class
audiences.

I'll illustrate how three
people in this setting

constructed identities that
deviated from these norms,

but were consistent with
their own deepest ideals.

In the process,
they effect change

for their families
and their communities.

So growing up, Marin
internalized messages

that women's
ultimate fulfillment

comes from caring
for home and family.

After many years as a
stay-at-home-mom, however,

she was depressed, and felt
like a failure for not being

satisfied with her
caregiving role.

She started to feel better
when she went to work,

but couldn't shake the guilt
for being away from her kids.
So after a year, she quit.

Unable to find a
place for herself

within her own
belief system, Marin

felt like her foundation
was crumbling.

After months of
questioning her beliefs,

she came to realize
that whether she

worked didn't have to be
tied to her other values.

She subsequently
returned to school,

and embarked on a career that
sparked greater joy and balance
to her family relationships.

Watching Marin
navigate this process

empowered her husband to
question social constraints

on his own working
family identities.

Inspired by her example, he
traded his corporate position

for a role that
supports his goal
to be closer to his children.

In another example,
[? Darrel ?] grew up

seeing little of his father,
who worked long hours to support
the family.

When his own children
were born, Darrel

decided that he wanted to be
more active in their lives.

As his career
progressed, he opted out

of extra shifts on the
weekend to be with his family

despite pressure in his
industry to work overtime.

After an interstate
moved for his wife's job,

he decided to hold off
on looking for work

so he could help his
family acclimate.

When he introduced himself to
the men of his community as

retired, explaining
that he was staying home

to take care of his
family, they didn't see
this as a legitimate option.

Eventually, Darrel
discovered that a position
had been set up for him.

Although he ultimately
accepted the position,

Darrel insisted on and
was given a schedule that

allows him to be at home
with his family after school

and to support the
kid's sporting events.

By prioritizing
caregiving, Darrel

serves as a role model
in his community,

but also, a quiet
advocate for flexible work

practices in a
male-dominated environment.

So not having worked
anything, but part-time

since her children
were growing up,

Peggy felt drawn to
attend medical school.

During the first
year of her program,

she worked crazy, nonstop
hours and battled guilt
over being away from her kids.

One day, a trusted
community leader

took her aside, and
told her she was

making a grave
mistake by putting
your children in daycare.

When she explained the emotions
and feelings that had fueled
her decision, he persisted.

Devastated by this
experience, Peggy
began questioning her choice.

After intense
soul-searching, she

had a profound experience that
strengthened her conviction
to be a doctor.

After she completed
medical school,

her husband was
disabled, leaving her

as the sole support
for her family.

And she credited her convictions
for being able to support them.

Now well-established
in a career she loves,

Peggy sees herself as a
role model for her daughters

and an advocate for
people in her community
whose lives don't fit the norm.

So what do we learn
from these examples?

Each of these people
charted a course

that didn't fit with the
community they belonged in.

When they faced pushback, they
revisited their convictions,

and decided to move forward
with what was important to them.

In the process, they
empowered other people

to also pursue a path that
was authentic to them.

So truly, we can be a force
for change for ourselves

and others when we
act courageously
with our convictions.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
